triples.name: Speech recognition
triples.relevance: The core task being studied is automatic speech recognition (ASR) and its disparities across racial groups.

triples.name: Machine learning
triples.relevance: ASR systems use sophisticated machine-learning algorithms to convert spoken language to text.

triples.name: Deep learning
triples.relevance: Advances in deep learning have significantly improved the quality of ASR systems.

triples.name: Virtual assistant
triples.relevance: Virtual assistants are one of the primary applications of ASR technology that the paper examines.

triples.name: Closed captioning
triples.relevance: Automated closed captioning is a key application of ASR systems that benefits from improved accuracy.

triples.name: Dictation machine
triples.relevance: Digital dictation platforms for healthcare are applications of ASR technology examined in the paper.

triples.name: Acoustic model
triples.relevance: Acoustic models are the underlying components of ASR systems that the paper identifies as a source of racial disparities.

triples.name: African-American Vernacular English
triples.relevance: The paper proposes using more diverse training datasets including AAVE to reduce racial disparities in ASR.

triples.name: Word error rate
triples.relevance: Word error rate (WER) is the key metric used to measure and compare disparities in ASR performance across racial groups.
